G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and applicable Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This action arises under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, including the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment codified at G.L. c. 186, § 14, and related Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 and 21.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 and 21, because this is a civil action within the jurisdictional limits of the Somerville District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 and G.L. c. 218, § 19 because the leased premises are located in Somerville, Middlesex County, and the events giving rise to this claim occurred there.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 and G.L. c. 218, § 19 because the leased premises are located in Somerville, Middlesex County, and the events giving rise to this claim occurred there.

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes a covenant of quiet enjoyment, both by statute (G.L. c. 186, § 14) and by common law. See, e.g., *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); *Winchester v. O’Brien*, 266 Mass. 33 (1929).
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The excerpt clearly recognizes an implied covenant/warranty of quiet enjoyment in the tenancies and applies it to find constructive eviction, but it does not discuss the statutory covenant under G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it state that every residential tenancy includes such a covenant by statute and common law. The opinion proceeds entirely on the basis of an implied/common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction, without mentioning the statute or articulating the broader, categorical proposition for all residential tenancies. Thus it partially supports the common-law aspect but not the full statutory-and-common-law proposition as framed.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). … Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises.

*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, 266 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes a covenant of quiet enjoyment, both by statute (G.L. c. 186, § 14) and by common law. See, e.g., *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); *Winchester v. O’Brien*, 266 Mass. 33 (1929).
*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, 266 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion proceeds entirely on an implied covenant / implied obligation arising from the lease and on tort/nuisance theories; it does not state that “every residential tenancy” includes a covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it cite or interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14. In fact, the lease here is for dental offices in an apartment house, i.e., a commercial use, and the court’s discussion is about implied covenants and wrongful interference with a tenant’s rights, not a general rule applicable to all residential tenancies. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the broad proposition claimed.
*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, 266 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The ‘grant of any thing carries an implication, that the grantee shall have all that is necessary to the enjoyment of the grant, so far as the grantor has power to give it.’ … The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … The same act may be a breach of the covenant for quiet enjoyment and also a wrong causing injury to the tenant for which injunctive relief might be sought or an action of tort would lie.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment imposes an affirmative duty on a landlord to refrain from conduct, or from allowing conduct within the landlord’s control, that substantially interferes with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment and explains that liability does not depend on malicious intent but on the landlord’s conduct where the “natural and probable consequence” is interference with the tenant’s rights. It further rejects the landlord’s argument that it was not responsible for third-party-caused flooding, holding the landlord liable because it had a duty to maintain sanitary, watertight premises and “permitted repeated flooding to occur” that interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. This aligns with an affirmative duty not to engage in, or allow within the landlord’s control, substantial interferences with use and enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights. … Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 283–284 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized that substantial interference with a tenant’s ability to sleep, rest, or use the premises comfortably may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. at 102–103 (repeated flooding, noise, and disturbances); *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 283–284 (1994).
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The court directly holds that if tenants are unable to use common areas such as sidewalks, streets, parking lots and recreation areas because of pervasive criminal activity, that "constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises." This squarely recognizes that substantial interference with tenants’ ability to live peacefully and enjoyably in their homes—including basic use of the premises—can be a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, consistent with the proposition.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. Cf. Ianello, supra at 323-324 (locking tenant out of common "conference room" which was part of inducement for him to enter into lease constituted breach of covenant).

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Defendant is the landlord of both Plaintiff and the upstairs tenants and therefore has control over the tenancies and the power to take reasonable steps to abate the nuisance, including enforcement of lease provisions, warnings, and, if necessary, termination or non‑renewal of the upstairs tenants’ tenancy. See *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. at 718–719; *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196, 199–200 (1979).
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: This opinion deals exclusively with the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement when a landlord fails to provide heat and hot water. It does not involve multiple tenancies, upstairs tenants, landlord control over different tenants, or any discussion of a landlord’s power or duty to abate a nuisance through lease enforcement, warnings, or termination. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the nuisance‑control proposition stated, and the citation to Berman for that purpose is inaccurate or at least unsupported by this text.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “When the tenant’s loss of heat occurred, G. L. c. 239, § 8A, permitted the tenant to withhold rent for Code violations only if ‘the owner . . . had not taken reasonable steps to remedy such conditions.’… The tenant may now withhold rent without considering whether the landlord is at fault or is taking reasonable steps to repair. As was the case in Hemingway, this statute provides for rent withholding, not rent abatement; but, as in Hemingway, we choose to permit a rent abatement as a matter of common law.”

*Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847.proposition: Under *Blackett* and its progeny, a landlord’s liability for breach of quiet enjoyment does not require proof of malicious intent; it is sufficient that the landlord’s acts or omissions were the natural and probable consequence of conditions he permitted to exist and failed to remedy. 371 Mass. at 718; see also *Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850–852 (1997).
*Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the level of landlord fault required under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and expressly reaffirms that malicious intent is not necessary. It clarifies that liability arises where the landlord’s negligent failure to address known conditions makes interference with quiet enjoyment the “natural and probable consequence” of the landlord’s acts or omissions. Although the case emphasizes a negligence/notice requirement and not strict liability, it squarely aligns with the proposition that proof of malicious intent is unnecessary and that liability may rest on the foreseeable consequences of conditions the landlord permitted to exist and failed to remedy.
*Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847.relevant_excerpt: “In Simon v. Solomon, supra at 101, we interpreted the new statute and concluded with respect to civil liability it was not necessary for a tenant to show malicious intent to recover against a landlord… Twelve years later, in Cruz… we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14… we have said that § 14 imposes liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.”

*Medeiros v. Bragg*, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 6.proposition: Defendant’s inaction in the face of known, continuing disturbances constitutes at least a knowing and willful disregard of Plaintiff’s rights under G.L. c. 186, § 14, entitling Plaintiff to statutory remedies, including up to three months’ rent or three times the actual damages, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees (if any are incurred). See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. at 102–103; *Medeiros v. Bragg*, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 639, 647–648 (2000).
*Medeiros v. Bragg*, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 6.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about racially discriminatory peremptory juror challenges and the Soares/Batson framework. It does not concern landlord-tenant law, G.L. c. 186, § 14, disturbances, or statutory remedies such as multiple rent damages and attorney’s fees. The citation to Medeiros v. Bragg for the stated landlord-tenant proposition is therefore inaccurate and not supported by the text of this opinion.
*Medeiros v. Bragg*, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 6.relevant_excerpt: “The difficulty in this case is that the record does not support the view that the prosecutor challenged the prospective juror on any racially neutral ground… In view of the absence of more precise information on the prosecutor’s rationale for exercising a peremptory challenge and where the defendant made a sufficient showing of impropriety, the jury selection process violated the defendant’s State and Federal constitutional rights to be tried by a fair and impartial jury.”

*Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Co.raw_text: *Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp.*, 340 Mass. 124, 127–128 (1959)
*Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Co.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes a breach of both the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, G.L. c. 186, § 14, and the express and implied covenants of quiet enjoyment contained in the Lease and under Massachusetts common law. See *Winchester v. O’Brien*, 266 Mass. 33, 36–37 (1929); *Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp.*, 340 Mass. 124, 127–128 (1959).
*Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Co.case_name: Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp.
*Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Co.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that a landlord’s serious, inexcusable failure to provide essential services (heat, power, elevator) to an upper-floor commercial tenant is a material breach of the lease that constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and can amount to a constructive eviction, excusing further performance and entitling the tenant to damages. Although the opinion does not discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14 specifically, it clearly supports the proposition that such conduct breaches both express and implied covenants of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts common law and under the lease. Thus, it is properly cited alongside Winchester as authority for a breach of quiet enjoyment based on deprivation of essential services.
*Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Co.relevant_excerpt: “Failure to furnish such services, at least if serious in extent and not excusable, deprives the lessee of a vital part of what the landlord knows the lessee must have in order to carry on his business. Such a failure constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment … and ‘enables the lessee to recover the damages caused to him thereby and also provides the lessee with the defense of “constructive eviction” (if he removes from the premises).’ … Such failure was a material breach of the lease and could be taken by Burt by abandoning the premises as a constructive eviction.”

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is independent of, and in addition to, other tenant protections such as the implied warranty of habitability under G.L. c. 239, § 8A and common law. See *Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 184, 194–198 (1973).

*Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 363 M.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is independent of, and in addition to, other tenant protections such as the implied warranty of habitability under G.L. c. 239, § 8A and common law. See *Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 184, 194–198 (1973).
*Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 363 M.support_reasoning: This portion of Hemingway is a concurring/dissenting opinion by Justice Quirico, not the majority, and it actually criticizes the majority’s broader implied warranty of habitability, arguing that landlord obligations should be tied to compliance with housing codes rather than a free‑standing, undefined warranty. The text does not discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment or its relationship to the implied warranty or to G.L. c. 239, § 8A. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that the covenant of quiet enjoyment is independent of and in addition to other tenant protections.
*Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “The point at which I dissent from the opinion of the court is where it attempts to accomplish the first step by resort to an implied warranty of the fitness of the rented dwelling unit instead of by the implication of an agreement that the unit will comply with the minimum standards required therefor by law. The court states the new rule to be that the landlord renting a dwelling unit impliedly warrants to the tenant ‘that the premises are fit for human occupation….’”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
